member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Annotations.AnnotationResourceResolver
member.summary: Base implementation of .

remarks.para: Uses assembly resources to look up the display name and label for an (and ) based on it's unique identifier.

The algorithm used is quite simple; all '.' characters in the unique identifier are replaced with '_' because the resource editor doesn't like '.'s, and one of the keywords "_DisplayName" or "_Label" is appended, giving the resource identifier to lookup.

An example would be a unique identifier of "Dicom.GeneralSeries.SeriesDescription". The resource identifiers to lookup would be "Dicom_GeneralSeries_SeriesDescription_DisplayName" and "Dicom_GeneralSeries_SeriesDescription_Label", respectively.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.BaseTools.MouseImageViewerTool
member.summary: Extends the class to provide functionality that is common to mouse tools.

remarks.para: A mouse tool is a tool that, when activated, is assigned to a specific mouse button (see ) and is given the opportunity to respond to mouse events for that button. Developers implementing mouse tools should subclass this class.

Typically, a mouse tool needs to be decorated with certain attributes in order to work properly. For example:
[C#] [MenuAction("activate", "imageviewer-contextmenu/My Tool", "Select", Flags = ClickActionFlags.CheckAction)] [MenuAction("activate", "global-menus/MenuTools/MenuStandard/My Tool", "Select", Flags = ClickActionFlags.CheckAction)] [ButtonAction("activate", "global-toolbars/ToolbarStandard/My Tool", "Select", Flags = ClickActionFlags.CheckAction)] [KeyboardAction("activate", "imageviewer-keyboard/ToolsStandard/My Tool", "Select", KeyStroke = XKeys.R)] [CheckedStateObserver("activate", "Active", "ActivationChanged")] [IconSet("activate", "Icons.MyToolSmall.png", "Icons.MyToolToolMedium.png", "Icons.MyToolToolLarge.png")] [MouseToolButton(XMouseButtons.Left, true)]
The "Select" parameter in each of the 'Action' attributes refers to the method which activates (and checks) the tool. All other tools with the same are deactivated.

When a tool does not implement the typical mouse button handling behaviour, it should not be decorated with any of the above attributes as it will result in unexpected behaviour with regards to the toolbars and menus.

A mouse tool can also have an additional mouse button shortcut specified (see ) that does not require the mouse tool to be activated in order to use it. The value of need not be modified (e.g. Ctrl, Shift), however if another tool's has the same value and is active, it will supersede any assignments. Therefore, should typically only be assigned a non-modified value when no other has the same value.

One further piece of functionality that subclasses of can choose to implement is handling of the mouse wheel. When decorated with a , the tool's will be set upon construction. The subclass must override the mouse wheel-related methods in order for the tool to have any effect (see , , , ).

member.summary: Handles a "start mouse" message from the Framework.
member.returns: A value indicating whether the start message was handled.

remarks.para: In most cases, corresponds to "mouse down".
As a developer, you need to override this method in your subclass to add your custom functionality, but you should never have to call it; it should only ever have to be called by the Framework.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.BaseTools.MouseImageViewerTool.Track(ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseInformation)
member.summary: Handles a "track mouse" message from the Framework.
member.returns: A value indicating whether the track message was handled.

remarks.para: In most cases, corresponds to "mouse move".

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.BaseTools.MouseImageViewerTool.Stop(ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseInformation)
member.summary: Handles a "stop mouse" message from the Framework.
member.returns: A value indicating whether the stop message was handled.

remarks.para: In most cases, corresponds to "mouse up".
As a developer, you need to override this method in your subclass to add your custom functionality, but you should never have to call it; it should only ever have to be called by the Framework.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics3D.CompositeGraphic3D.Visible
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this is visible.
member.remarks: Setting the property will not recursively set the property for child objects in the subtree for reasons of preservation of state. For example, if a at the very top of the scene graph had many child graphics whose visibility were dependent on, say, the position of the mouse, when the 's visibility changed, the visibility of the child objects would no longer be correct. Also, when a parent graphic's property is false, it's children are not rendered regardless of the value of their property.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics3D.IGraphic3D.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of this .
member.remarks: This vallue need not be unique, and should be used to indicate a logical equivalence or relation between multiple graphics. The property should be used to identify separate and distinct instances. For example, can be used to logically group multiple graphics in the same scene graph together, or to logically equate one graphic with another in a pair of image clones.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics3D.IGraphic3D.Uid
member.summary: Gets a value uniquely identifying this instance.
member.remarks: This value shall be unique, even for clones, as they are separate and distinct instances. The property should be used to indicate a logical equivalence or relation between multiple graphics. For example, can be used to correlate graphic model objects and the renderer object used to render the model.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics3D.IOverlayGraphics3DProvider
member.summary: Provides access to a containing user-level graphics.

remarks.para: User-level graphics are rendered after any domain-level graphics and after any application-level graphics.
If you have subclassed and want to expose a to objects, do so by implementing this interface in your subclass.

In general, avoid accessing members of subclasses of directly. Prefer instead to use provider interfaces such as this one. Doing so prevents objects from having to know about specific subclasses of , thus allowing them to work with any type of that implements the provider interface.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics.ColorBarGraphic.Reversed
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether or not the spectrum should be reversed in order.
member.remarks: Normally, the colours of the spectrum are arranged such that left-to-right or top-to-bottom (depending on ) coincides with increasing pixel intensity values. This behaviour can be reversed using this property such that low intensity values are to the right or bottom, and high intensity values are to the left or top.

member.summary: Gets the point on the closest to the specified point.

member.returns: The point on the graphic closest to the given .

remarks.para: Depending on the value of , the computation will be carried out in either source or destination coordinates.

Since the interpolation between nodes of the curve is not explicitly defined, this method returns the closest node to the specified point, and ignores the individual curve segments for the purposes of this calculation.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics.IApplicationGraphicsProvider
member.summary: Provides access to a containing application-level graphics.

remarks.para: Application-level graphics are rendered after any domain-level graphics and before any user-level graphics.
If you have subclassed and want to expose a to objects, do so by implementing this interface in your subclass.

In general, avoid accessing members of subclasses of directly. Prefer instead to use provider interfaces such as this one. Doing so prevents objects from having to know about specific subclasses of , thus allowing them to work with any type of that implements the provider interface.

member.summary: Gets or sets the location that the arrowhead points to.

remarks.para: This property specifies the point that the arrowhead points to, as well as the point to which it is fixed. As the parent zoom changes, the screen size of arrowhead will remain the same, and this point will remain pointing to the same location in the parent graphic.
This property can be specified in either source or destination coordinates depending on the value of .

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics.InvariantArrowheadGraphic.Angle
member.summary: Gets or sets the angle in degrees in which the arrowhead points.
member.remarks: The angle is specified in terms of the standard polar coordinate axes relative to the parent's (i.e. counterclockwise from the positive X-axis).

member.summary: Gets or sets the length of the arrowhead.

member.summary: A grayscale .

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics.GrayscaleImageGraphic.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of with the specified image parameters.

remarks.para: Creates an empty grayscale image of a specific size. By default, all pixels are set to zero (i.e., black). Useful as a canvas on which pixels can be set by the client.
By default, the image is 16-bit unsigned with bits stored = 16, high bit = 15, rescale slope = 1.0 and rescale intercept = 0.0.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics.GrayscaleImageGraphic.NormalizationLut
member.summary: Gets or sets a LUT to normalize the output of the modality LUT immediately prior to the VOI LUT.

remarks.para: In most cases, this should be left NULL. However, some PET images have a very small rescale slope (<< 1) and thus need this to fix the input to the VOI LUT.
At any rate, DO NOT use the output of this LUT for any purpose other than as an input to the VOI LUT, as it is meaningless otherwise.

member.summary: Retrieves this image's Voi Lut.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics.GrayscaleImageGraphic.PresentationLut
member.summary: Gets this image's presentation LUT.
member.remarks: You should not need to set this property unless you are writing a custom renderer for 10-bit grayscale (for example) displays, or need an alternate range of p-values for some other output device. Otherwise, this property is managed internally, assuming an 8-bit display.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics.InvariantPrimitive
member.summary: A whose size in destination coordinates is invariant under zoom.
member.remarks: Sometimes it is desirable to have a whose size is invariant under zoom, but whose position is not. A good example are the objects on measurement tools that allow a user to stretch and resize the measurement. They are anchored to a certain point on the underlying image so that when zoomed, the control point appears to "move" with the zoom of the image, but their size in screen pixels remains the same.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics.CoordinateSystem
member.summary: Coordinate system enumeration.

remarks.para: Consider a 512x512 image that has anchored to it a line defined by points P1(0,0) and P2(10,10), where those points are in the coordinate system of the image. In that case, the line is said to be in source coordinates. Now consider if the image is zoomed by 2x where the center of expansion is (0,0). In that case, the line's source coordinates are still the same, but its destination or Tile coordinates are now P1'(0,0), P2'(20,20).

In general, the source coordinates of a particular are coordinates in the coordinate system of its immediate parent. Destination coordinates are coordinates in the coordinate system of the root of the scene graph, i.e., the Tile. Put another way, destination coordinates = T(source coordinates), where T represents the a graphic's cumulative transformation.

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics.CoordinateSystem.Source
member.summary: Represent a object's coordinates in its immediate parent's, or source coordinate system.

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics.CoordinateSystem.Destination
member.summary: Represent a object's coordinates in the coordinate system of the root of the scene graph, that is, in Tile or destination coordinates.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Graphics.CompositeGraphic.Visible
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this is visible.
member.remarks: Setting the property will not recursively set the property for child objects in the subtree for reasons of preservation of state. For example, if a at the very top of the scene graph had many child graphics whose visibility were dependent on, say, the position of the mouse, when the 's visibility changed, the visibility of the child objects would no longer be correct. Also, when a parent graphic's property is false, it's children are not rendered regardless of the value of their property.

member.summary: Performs batch LUT value lookup against a black box implementation.
member.remarks: This method just calls the indexer in a tight loop, which will generally not provide optimal performance. It is recommended that a custom implementation be used instead of calling this method in order to take advantage of the knowledge of the lookup's internal details.
member.param: Source array of input values to be transformed.

Number of values in the arrays to transform (contiguous entries from start of array).
The with which to transform the input values.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Imaging.LutFunctions.LookupLut(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs batch LUT value lookup against the specified lookup table data.

remarks.para: The values are transformed according to the following algorithm:
remarks.code:
if input <= firstMappedInputValue then
output = lutData[0]
else if input >= lastMappedInputValue then
output = lutData[lutData.Length - 1]
else
output = lutData[input - firstMappedInputValue]

member.param: Source array of input values to be transformed (values are rounded to nearest integer).
Destination array where transformed output values will be written (may be same array as ).
Number of values in the arrays to transform (contiguous entries from start of array).
LUT table mapping input values to output values.
The input value corresponding to the first element of .
The input value corresponding to the last element of .

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Imaging.LutFunctions.LookupLut(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs batch LUT value lookup against the specified lookup table data.

remarks.para: The values are transformed according to the following algorithm:
remarks.code:
if input <= firstMappedInputValue then
output = lutData[0]
else if input >= lastMappedInputValue then
output = lutData[lutData.Length - 1]
else
output = lutData[input - firstMappedInputValue]

member.param: Source array of input values to be transformed (values are rounded to nearest integer).
Destination array where transformed output values will be written (may be same array as ).
Number of values in the arrays to transform (contiguous entries from start of array).
LUT table mapping input values to output values.
The input value corresponding to the first element of .
The input value corresponding to the last element of .

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Imaging.LutFunctions.LookupLinearRescale(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs batch LUT value lookup by applying a linear rescale of the input range to the output range.

remarks.para: The values are transformed according to the following algorithm:
remarks.code:
if input <= minInputValue then
output = minOutputValue
else if input >= maxInputValue then
output = maxOutputValue
else
output = Round((input - minInputValue)*(maxOutputValue - minOutputValue)/(maxInputValue - minInputValue) + minOutputValue)

member.param: Source array of input values to be transformed.
Destination array where transformed output values will be written (may be same array as ).
Number of values in the arrays to transform (contiguous entries from start of array).
Specifies the lower bound of the range of input values.
Specifies the upper bound of the range of input values.
Specifies the lower bound of the range of output values.
Specifies the upper bound of the range of output values.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Imaging.LutFunctions.LookupVoiWindowLinear(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Performs batch LUT value lookup by applying a linear VOI window rescaling.

remarks.para: The values are transformed according to the VOI window algorithm defined in DICOM 2011 PS 3.3 C.11.2.1.2:
remarks.code:
if input <= center - 0.5 - (width - 1)/2 then
output = minOutputValue
else if input > center - 0.5 + (width - 1)/2 then
output = maxOutputValue
else
output = ((input - (center - 0.5))/(width - 1) + 0.5)*(maxOutputValue - minOutputValue) + minOutputValue

member.param: Source array of input values to be transformed.
Destination array where transformed output values will be written (may be same array as ).
Number of values in the arrays to transform (contiguous entries from start of array).
The centre value of the VOI window.
The width of the VOI window.
Specifies the lower bound of the range of output values.
Specifies the upper bound of the range of output values.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Imaging.LutFunctions.LookupClampValue(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Performs batch LUT value lookup by clamping the output range, but otherwise passing values through without transformation.

remarks.para: The values are transformed according to the following algorithm:
remarks.code: if input < minValue then output = minValue else if input > maxValue then output = maxValue else output = input

member.param: Source array of input values to be transformed.
Destination array where transformed output values will be written (may be same array as ).
Number of values in the arrays to transform (contiguous entries from start of array).
Specifies the lower bound of the range of values.
Specifies the upper bound of the range of values.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Imaging.OverlayData.UnpackFromPixelData(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Extracts an overlay embedded in a DICOM Pixel Data buffer and unpacks it to form an 8-bit overlay pixel data buffer.

remarks.para: Embedded overlays were last defined in the 2004 DICOM Standard. Since then, their usage has been retired. As such, there is no mechanism to directly read or encode embedded overlays. This method may be used as a helper to extract overlays in images encoded with a previous version of the standard for display in compatibility mode or storage as packed bit data.

This overload processes all pixel allocations in the pixel data buffer. If the pixel data contains mutliple image frames, the unpacked overlay data buffer will also be multi-frame (with the key difference that the overlay data will always be 8 bits per pixel, rather than potentially 16 bits per pixel).

member.param: The bit position of the overlay plane within the pixel data buffer.
The number of bits allocated per pixel. Must be 8 or 16.
A value indicating if the pixel data buffer is stored as 16-bit words with big endian byte ordering.
The DICOM Pixel Data buffer containing an embedded overlay.
member.returns: The unpacked, 8-bit overlay pixel data buffer.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Imaging.OverlayData.UnpackFromPixelData(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Extracts an overlay embedded in a DICOM Pixel Data buffer and unpacks it to form an 8-bit overlay pixel data buffer.

remarks.para: Embedded overlays were last defined in the 2004 DICOM Standard. Since then, their usage has been retired. As such, there is no mechanism to directly read or encode embedded overlays. This method may be used as a helper to extract overlays in images encoded with a previous version of the standard for display in compatibility mode or storage as packed bit data.

member.param: The bit position of the overlay plane within the pixel data buffer.
The number of bits allocated per pixel. Must be 8 or 16.
The 0-based index of the image frame from which an overlay plane is to be extracted.
The size of an image frame in bytes.
A value indicating if the pixel data buffer is stored as 16-bit words with big endian byte ordering.
The DICOM Pixel Data buffer containing an embedded overlay.
member.returns: The unpacked, 8-bit overlay pixel data buffer.

member.summary: A colour pixel wrapper.

Use these methods judiciously, as the convenience comes at the expense of performance. For example, if you're doing complex image processing, using methods such as is not recommended if you want good performance. Instead, use the property to get the raw byte array, then use unsafe code to do your processing.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Imaging.LutComposer
member.summary: Combines various objects together in the standard grayscale image display pipeline.

remarks.para:
The sub-functions of the standard imaging display pipeline are, in order:
Name Description
Modality LUT Transforms stored pixel values to manufacturer-independent values.
Normalization LUT Performs any additional transformation prior to selecting the VOI range, as may be necessary in some PET images.
Values-of-Interest (VOI) LUT Selects range from manufacturer-independent values for display.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Imaging.PixelData
member.summary: A pixel data wrapper.
member.remarks: provides a number of convenience methods to make accessing and changing pixel data easier. Use these methods judiciously, as the convenience comes at the expense of performance. For example, if you're doing complex image processing, using methods such as is not recommended if you want good performance. Instead, use the property to get the raw byte array, then use unsafe code to do your processing.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Imaging.PixelData.Raw
member.summary: Gets the raw pixel data.

remarks.para: Use the byte array returned by this property to do unsafe processing.

In general, you should avoid storing the byte array if at all possible. By storing it for say, the lifetime of an , future memory management schemes will be unable to release it, since a reference will have been created to it that such schemes may not be able to reach. If you do need to store the byte array for some reason, do so only using local variables, since they have only method scope and can be garbage collected easily.

member.summary: Gets the pixel value at the specific pixel index.
member.param: The index.
member.remarks: If the pixel data is treated as a one-dimensional array where each row of pixels is concatenated, is the index into that array. This is useful when you know the index of the pixel that you want to get and don't want to incur the needless computational overhead associated with specifying an x and y value.

member.summary: Used in conjunction with for pixel processing.
member.param: The ith pixel processed so far. This is a zero based index. If iterating over the entire image, is the same as .
The x value of the current pixel being processed.
The y value of the current pixel being processed
The index of the pixel being processed.
member.remarks: It is often desirable to iterate through the pixels in an image, or the pixels in a rectangular region in an image so that some kind of processing can be done. When used in conjunction with or , this delegate allows the client to focus on writing the processing code, not the boilerplate iteration code.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseButtonHandler
member.summary: An interface for objects that handle mouse button input.

remarks.para: The framework will look for this interface first on graphic objects () in the current 's SceneGraph (see ), then on s belonging to the current (via ) and if an appropriate one is found, it will be given capture.

An gets capture by returning true from indicating to the framework that it would like to handle mouse button input. Similarly, capture is not released until returns false, or is called by the framework.
When an has capture, all mouse input defined by the interface is handled by the object with capture. No other objects receive any input until capture is released.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseButtonHandler.Start(ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseInformation)
member.summary: Called by the framework each time a mouse button is pressed.
member.remarks: As a general rule, if the object did anything as a result of this call, it must return true. If false is returned, is called on other s until one returns true.
member.returns: True if the did something as a result of the call, and hence would like to receive capture. Otherwise, false.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseButtonHandler.Track(ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseInformation)
member.summary: Called by the framework when the mouse has moved.
member.remarks: A button does not necessarily have to be down for this message to be called. The framework can call it any time the mouse moves.
member.returns: True if the message was handled, otherwise false.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseButtonHandler.Stop(ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseInformation)
member.summary: Called by the framework when the mouse button is released.
member.returns: True if the framework should not release capture, otherwise false.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseButtonHandler.Cancel
member.summary: Called by the framework to let perform any necessary cleanup when capture is going to be forcibly released.
member.remarks: It is important that this method is implemented correctly and doesn't simply do nothing when it is inappropriate to do so, otherwise odd behaviour may be experienced.

member.summary: Allows the to override certain default framework behaviour.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.TileController
member.summary: This class controls the behaviour of objects in the , namely the s in the current 's SceneGraph () and s belonging to the current , specifically those that implement and/or .

remarks.para:
- The receives messages from the view layer, interprets them, and allows the appropriate domain objects to handle the messages in a prescribed manner. Here is a (highly simplified) description of how it works:
- When the mouse moves without any buttons down, all s that implement have their method called.
- When a mouse button is clicked, an is searched for at the current mouse position that implements . If one is found, it is given 'capture' until it releases capture or capture is canceled by the framework. If no is found, then all of the current 's s are searched for an and the same rules are applied.
- When the right mouse button is clicked, the same thing occurs as for the left mouse button, but when it is released, a context menu is shown provided the mouse didn't move more than a couple of pixels.
When the mouse wheel is used, a similar approach is taken as mentioned above for s, but for s. However, only s are given the opportunity to handle the mouse wheel, not s.
Note that this object is instantiated from within the view layer and cannot be accessed from application or domain level code. This is deliberate as it is intended for internal framework use only.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Comparers.ComparerBase.Compare(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.IComparable},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.IComparable})
member.summary: Compares two sets of values, where the position of the items in corresponds with the position of the items in .
member.remarks: Item pairs are compared in order until the first non-equal pair is found, at which point comparison stops and a result is returned. The number of items in and must always yield the same number of entries, or an may be thrown.
member.returns: Zero when all entry pairs are equal, otherwise +-.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InteractiveGraphics.ContextMenuControlGraphic.GetExportedActions(System.String,ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseInformation)
member.summary: Gets a set of exported s.

remarks.para: This mechanism is useful when a particular component defines generally useful s without requiring specific knowledge of the action model sites that the client code uses.

Overriding implementations should generally call the base implementation and invoke a with any new actions the derived class wishes to provide in order to maintain full functionality of any control graphics further down in the chain.

member.param: The action model site at which the actions should reside.
The mouse input when the action model was requested, such as in response to a context menu request.
member.returns: A set of exported s.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InteractiveGraphics.ControlGraphic.ClearCanvas#ImageViewer#InputManagement#IMouseButtonHandler#Start(ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseInformation)
member.summary: Called by the framework each time a mouse button is pressed.

remarks.para: As a general rule, if the object did anything as a result of this call, it must return true. If false is returned, is called on other s until one returns true.
The implementation finds a handler by trying , and any child graphics implementing , in decreasing order of priority.

member.param: The mouse input information.
member.returns: True if the did something as a result of the call and hence would like to receive capture; False otherwise.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InteractiveGraphics.ControlGraphic.ClearCanvas#ImageViewer#InputManagement#IMouseButtonHandler#Track(ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseInformation)
member.summary: Called by the framework when the mouse has moved.

remarks.para: A button does not necessarily have to be down for this message to be called. The framework can call it any time the mouse moves.
The implementation calls on the current handler, , or any child graphics implementing , in decreasing order of priority.

member.param: The mouse input information.
member.returns: True if the message was handled; False otherwise.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InteractiveGraphics.ControlGraphic.ClearCanvas#ImageViewer#InputManagement#IMouseButtonHandler#Stop(ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseInformation)
member.summary: Called by the framework when the mouse button is released.

remarks.para: The implementation calls on the current handler, , or any child graphics implementing , in decreasing order of priority.

member.param: The mouse input information.
member.returns: True if the framework should not release capture; False otherwise.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InteractiveGraphics.ControlGraphic.ClearCanvas#ImageViewer#InputManagement#IMouseButtonHandler#Cancel
member.summary: Called by the framework to let perform any necessary cleanup when capture is going to be forcibly released.

remarks.para: The implementation calls on the current handler or in decreasing order of priority.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InteractiveGraphics.ControlGraphic.Behaviour
member.summary: Gets the desired behaviour of this mouse input handler.
member.remarks: The default implementation returns the behaviour of the lowest control graphic in the control chain, or if this graphic is the lowest in the control chain.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InteractiveGraphics.ControlGraphic.GetExportedActions(System.String,ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InputManagement.IMouseInformation)
member.summary: Gets a set of exported s.

remarks.para: This mechanism is useful when a particular component defines generally useful s without requiring specific knowledge of the action model sites that the client code uses.

Overriding implementations should generally call the base implementation and invoke a with any new actions the derived class wishes to provide in order to maintain full functionality of any control graphics further down in the chain.

member.param: The action model site at which the actions should reside.
The mouse input when the action model was requested, such as in response to a context menu request.
member.returns: A set of exported s.

member.summary: Interactive builder class that interprets mouse clicks as ordered vertices to setup a closed .
member.remarks: This builder takes input until the the maximum number of vertices is reached, the user clicks near the first point or the user double clicks anywhere, after which the graphic is complete and control is released. A visual cue is shown when the cursor is close enough to the first point to snap and close the polygon.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InteractiveGraphics.AnnotationGraphic
member.summary: An standard, stateful interactive graphic that consists of some subject of interest graphic and a text callout that describes the subject.

remarks.para: essentially acts as a template for any kind of interactive graphic defining some object of interest. The subject of interest can be any graphic primitive such as a line, a rectangle, an ellipse, etc., or some hierarchy of s decorating a primitive graphic.
By default, the callout line will snap to the nearest point on the .

member.summary: Called by the framework each time a mouse button is pressed.

member.summary: Called by the framework to let perform any necessary cleanup when capture is going to be forcibly released.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.InteractiveGraphics.MoveControlGraphic.Anchor
member.summary: Gets a point that can be used as a landmark to quantify the difference in position of the controlled graphic when moved by this .

remarks.para: This point has no meaning outside of the same instance of a . Specifically, there is no defined relationship between the and the underlying . The typical usage is to take the difference between the current value and a previous reading of the value to determine the position delta between the two readings.
This point is given in either source or destination coordinates depending on the current value of .

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Mathematics.Rectangle3D
member.summary: Stores a set of six float-point numbers that represent the location and dimensions of a rectangular cuboid.
member.remarks: This class uses a right-handed convention for axes - the direction of the third axis is determined by the cross product of the left-to-right vector and the top-to-bottom vectors, which yields the vector front-to-back.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Mathematics.PolygonF.Contains(System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary: Tests if a point lies within the boundaries of the polygon.
member.remarks: This method is indeterminate for points lying exactly on the boundaries of the polygon, and may test either true or false (but will not throw an exception either way). The distribution of results is approximately even, and thus this method can be used in statistical calculations.
member.param: The test point.
member.returns: True if the polygon contains the given point; False otherwise.

member.summary: Computes the area of the polygon.
member.returns: The area of the polygon in square units.

member.summary: Counts the number of counter-clockwise windings that the polygon makes around a given point.
member.param: The test point.
member.returns: The number of counter-clockwise windings.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Mathematics.PolygonF.ComputeSimpleArea(System.Drawing.PointF*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Green's Theorem-derived formula to compute the area of the polygon.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Mathematics.PolygonF.CountWindings(System.Drawing.PointF,System.Drawing.PointF*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Counts the number of counter-clockwise windings that the polygon makes around a given point.
member.param: The test point.
A pointer to the array of vertices defining the polygon.
The number of vertices in the array.
member.returns: The number of CCW windings.
member.remarks: Algorithm as given on http://softsurfer.com/Archive/algorithm_0103/algorithm_0103.htm.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Mathematics.FloatComparer
member.summary: A utility class to facilitate error-tolerant comparison of floating point values.

remarks.para: Floating point variables store decimal numbers as a significand (the significant figures part of the number) and an exponent. As a result, floating point arithmetic has the potential to introduce errors in computation due to the inability to represent certain values as a floating point variable.

In order to compare floating point values in a robust manner, it is necessary to compare such values while allowing for a limited amount of error. The actual amount of acceptible tolernace that should be used will depend on the context of the computation.

Throughout this class, tolerance may be expressed in terms of the number of ULPs ("Unit in Last Place"), a unit based on the minimum representable value of the significand. Alternatively, tolerance may also be expressed as an "absolute" value, in which case the equality comparision is carried out ± absolute tolerance.
The comparison algorithms used in this class are based on the code presented at http://www.windojitsu.com/code/floatcomparer.html.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Mathematics.FloatComparer.Compare(System.Single,System.Single,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two floating point values within a specified tolerance in ULPs.
member.param: One floating point value to be compared.
Other floating point value to be compared.
The tolerance for equality in terms of ULPs.
member.returns: 0 if equals ± ULPs; +1 if x > y + tolerance ULPs; -1 if x < y - tolerance ULPs.
member.exception: Thrown if is negative or in excess of 222 (the limit of the significand in a single-precision floating point value).

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Mathematics.FloatComparer.Compare(System.Single,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Compares two floating point values within a specified tolerance in ULPs.
member.param: One floating point value to be compared.
Other floating point value to be compared.
The tolerance for equality in terms of ULPs.
The difference between the values in terms of ULPs.
member.returns: 0 if = ± ULPs; +1 if x > y + tolerance ULPs; -1 if x < y - tolerance ULPs.
member.exception: Thrown if is negative or in excess of 222 (the limit of the significand in a single-precision floating point value).

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Mathematics.FloatComparer.AreEqual(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Compares two floating point values for equality within a specified absolute tolerance.
member.param: One floating point value to be compared.
Other floating point value to be compared.
The absolute tolerance.
member.returns: True if = ± ; False otherwise.

member.summary: Compares two floating point values for equality within 100 ULPs.

Other floating point value to be compared.
member.returns: True if = ± 100 ULPs; False otherwise.
member.remarks: A tolerance of 100 ULPs is assumed.

member.returns: True if > + 100 ULPs; False otherwise.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Mathematics.RectangleUtilities
member.summary: A collection of utility methods that operation on rectangles.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Mathematics.RectangleUtilities.Intersect(System.Drawing.RectangleF,System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Computes the intersection between two rectangles.
member.remarks:
.NET's Rectangle class does not properly compute intersections between rectangles when either the height and/or width is negative.
NOTE: the order in which rectangles are passed into this function is IMPORTANT! The function maintains the sense/direction (of the width and height) of the first rectangle passed in.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Mathematics.RectangleUtilities.RoundInflate(System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Rounds the 4 sides (top, left, right, bottom) to integer values, but it does not do typical float-style rounding. The values are rounded away from the center of the rectangle.
member.returns: A new rectangle that has been rounded away from the centre of the original input rectangle.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Mathematics.RectangleUtilities.DoesIntersect(System.Drawing.RectangleF,System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Determines if the two input rectangles intersect at all.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Mathematics.RectangleUtilities.MakeRectangleZeroBased(System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Shrinks the bottom and right coordinates of a rectangle by 1.
member.remarks: When using a Rectangle's left, top, right, bottom paramters as coordinates, (say, when identifying pixel location in an image) it is often useful for the right and bottom parameters to be exactly one less. For example, if a Bitmap is 10x10 and represented by Rectangle(0,0,10,10) calling Bitmap.GetPixel(right, bottom) won't work. However, it does work if the bitmap is represented by Rectangle(0,0,9,9). Note that if the width and/or height of the rectangle is negative, this method will shrink the left and/or top values by one instead.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.Dicom.DicomGraphicsPlane.UserOverlays
member.summary: Gets a collection of existing user-created overlays.
member.remarks: This collection gives client code a collection to insert any dynamically created overlay planes which may not necessarily have an assigned overlay plane group. During DICOM softcopy presentation state serialization, visible overlays in this collection will be given priority for serialization, since only 16 overlays can be serialized.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.Dicom.IDicomGraphicsPlaneLayers.InactiveLayer
member.summary: Gets the inactive layer.
member.remarks: The inactive layer is a special layer with an empty (0-length) . This layer is never shown in the scene graph, and s can be moved here to disable their display. Alternatively, the property can be set on individual objects, but certain DICOM objects (such as overlays from presentation states) require a layer to be explicitly identified and, if the identified layer is the 0-length ID, should be disabled.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.Dicom.OverlayPlaneGraphic.#ctor(ClearCanvas.Dicom.Iod.Modules.OverlayPlane,System.Byte[],ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.Dicom.OverlayPlaneSource)
member.summary: Constructs an for a single-frame overlay plane using a pre-processed overlay pixel data buffer.

remarks.para: This overload should only be used for single-frame overlay planes. Multi-frame overlay planes should process the overlay data into separate buffers and then construct individual graphics using .

The parameter allows for the specification of an alternate source of overlay pixel data, such as the unpacked contents of or the extracted, inflated overlay pixels of . Although the format should be 8-bits per pixel, every pixel should either be 0 or 255. This will allow pixel interpolation algorithms sufficient range to produce a pleasant image. (If the data was either 0 or 1, regardless of the bit-depth, most interpolation algorithms will interpolate 0s for everything in between!)

member.param: The IOD object containing properties of the overlay plane.
The overlay pixel data in 8-bits per pixel format, with each pixel being either 0 or 255.
A value identifying the source of the overlay plane.
member.exception: Thrown if is NULL or 0-length.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.Dicom.OverlayPlaneGraphic.#ctor(ClearCanvas.Dicom.Iod.Modules.OverlayPlane,System.Byte[],System.Int32,ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.Dicom.OverlayPlaneSource)
member.summary: Constructs an for a single or multi-frame overlay plane using a pre-processed overlay pixel data buffer.

remarks.para: The parameter allows for the specification of an alternate source of overlay pixel data, such as the unpacked contents of or the extracted, inflated overlay pixels of . Although the format should be 8-bits per pixel, every pixel should either be 0 or 255. This will allow pixel interpolation algorithms sufficient range to produce a pleasant image. (If the data was either 0 or 1, regardless of the bit-depth, most interpolation algorithms will interpolate 0s for everything in between!)

member.param: The IOD object containing properties of the overlay plane.
The overlay pixel data in 8-bits per pixel format, with each pixel being either 0 or 255.
The overlay frame index (0-based). Single-frame overlays should specify 0.
A value identifying the source of the overlay plane.
member.exception: Thrown if is NULL or 0-length.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.Dicom.OverlayPlaneGraphic.GrayPresentationValue
member.summary: Gets or sets the 16-bit grayscale presentation value in which the overlay should be drawn.
member.remarks: DICOM overlays are strictly 1-bit images, so each overlay pixels is either present or not. The display of present pixels is no longer defined by the data source but is now implementation specific. The and properties allows this display to be customized by client code. A null value for causes the to be used.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.Dicom.DicomSoftcopyPresentationStateBase`1.RelationshipSets
member.summary: Gets a for this data set.
member.remarks: As of the 2008 version of the DICOM standard, only the Blended Softcopy Presentation State IOD defines multiple presentation state relationship modules (as part of the presentation state blending module). Thus, only the implementation of the Blended Softcopy Presentation State should override this member to provide all the individual relationship modules. The default implementation assumes the module is available as a root member of the IOD.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.Dicom.DicomSoftcopyPresentationStateBase`1.ConvertToPixelAddressRectangle(System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Computes a rectangle specifying the 1-based pixel address and the row and column offset to get the pixel address of the opposite corner given a rectangle specifying the 0-based coordinate and size (whose width and height need not be positive).
member.param: The 0-based rectangle specified as a 0-based coordinate and a size.
member.returns: An equivalent rectangle specifying the 1-based pixel address of the coordinate and row and column offset to get the pixel address of the opposite corner.
member.exception: Thrown if the given rectangle has zero-area, as it cannot be represented in a 1-based pixel address rectangle.

remarks.para: In DICOM and certain other applications, areas of images are identified with the first pixel being at position row 1 and column 1. In most Windows graphics rendering systems, imaging coordinates are identified as an infinitesimal point at the top-left corner of a given pixel and the coordinates are given in a 0-based system (that is, the first pixel has a coordinate of (0,0)).

It is trivial to compute the addresses of the pixels included within the rectangle when the rectangle is positively-oriented (has positive width and height) since the left most pixels are in column +1, the right most pixels are in column +, and so on. It is somewhat more complicated to compute when the rectangle is not positively-oriented due to the singularities when either or is 0 (and hence rectangles having zero-area cannot be specified as a pixel address rectangle - a pixel address rectangle having size 0x0 is considered as containing 1 row and 1 column).

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.Dicom.DicomSoftcopyPresentationStateBase`1.DeserializeBitmapDisplayShutter(ClearCanvas.Dicom.Iod.Modules.BitmapDisplayShutterModuleIod,`0)

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.Dicom.DisplayAreaSerializationOption
member.summary: Enumerated values that specify how the displayed area of an image should be serialized in a presentation state.

remarks.para: If the image with presentation state is being rendered in a screen rectangle of the same size as when the presentation state was created, then the displayed area is the same. However, this is the exception rather than the norm. The typical use case for presentation states would have the rendering of the image take place on a different workstation, typically with differing physical monitor size, screen resolution, window dimensions, window aspect ratio, etc. These enumerated values serve to specify which quality of the visible area should be preserved in such circumstances.
An alternative description can be found in DICOM Standard 2008, PS 3.3 C.10.4.

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.Dicom.DisplayAreaSerializationOption.SerializeAsDisplayedArea
member.summary: Specifies that maintaining the same minimum visible area has higher precedence over maintaining the same magnification.
member.remarks: In cases where the aspect ratio of the screen rectangle where the image and presentation state is being rendered differs from that of the creator, then the magnification will be adjusted such that, at a minimum, the original visible area remains completely visible.

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.Dicom.DisplayAreaSerializationOption.SerializeAsTrueSize
member.summary: Specifies that maintaining the true physical size of the image has higher precedence over maintaining the same visible area.

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.Dicom.DisplayAreaSerializationOption.SerializeAsMagnification
member.summary: Specifies that maintaining the same magnification ratio has higher precedence over maintaining the same visible area.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.PresentationStates.PresentationStateGraphic
member.summary: The graphic at the root of the scene graph that handles deserializing of the image's presentation state.

remarks.para: s can insert this graphic at the root of the scene graphic before the and other s in order to give the presentation state a first chance to set up the display and other graphics further down the scene graph before it is drawn for the first time.
The presentation state is only deserialized on the first draw after construction or after the property changes.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.RendererBase2`2
member.summary: Base class for a strongly-typed .

remarks.para: See the remarks section for regarding the thread-safety of this object (it is not thread-safe). For this reason, you should use this class in tandem with the , although it is not required that you do so.

This base class differs from in that it is strongly-typed, provides more flexibility in implementation (particularly for 3D rendering technologies where objects need to be instantiated on a per-surface basis, rather than rasterizing the models from within this class.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.RendererFactoryBase
member.summary: Provides base implementation for a Render Factory.
member.remarks: Inheritors must also derive from in order to use this class (it calls to allocate a new from within the factory method. Note that only one object is actually allocated per thread, and is wrapped in an internal proxy object. This is because the object is purposely not thread-safe to make it easier for inheritors to implement. However, there is nothing stopping a developer from deriving directly from and creating their own Singleton thread-safe renderer.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.DrawArgs.Dpi
member.summary: Gets or sets the resolution of the output device in DPI to be used in scaling vector graphics appropriately.
member.remarks: The vector graphics are drawn for display at a nominal screen resolution (usually 96 DPI). If the destination output device has a significantly larger DPI, setting this value will allow font sizes and line widths to be scaled appropriately so that the size of the vector graphics relative to the rest of the image remains relatively constant.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.IRenderer
member.summary: Defines an renderer.
member.remarks: Unless you are implementing your own renderer, you should never have to interact with this interface. The two methods on should only ever have to be called by the Framework, and thus should be treated as internal.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.IRenderer.CreateRenderingSurface(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.RenderingSurfaceType)
member.summary: Creates an instance of suitable for this renderer.
member.param: The window ID. On Windows systems, this is the window handle or "HWND".
The width of the surface.
The height of the surface.
A value indicating the type of rendering surface requested.
member.remarks: This method is called by TileControl (i.e., the view) whenever it is resized, which includes when the control is first created. Once TileControl has obtained the surface, it just holds onto it. Your implementation of should just render to the that same surface (passed in via the ) irrespective of the being rendered.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.IRenderer.Draw(ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.DrawArgs)
member.summary: Renders the specified scene graph to the graphics surface.
member.remarks: Calling code should take care to handle any exceptions in a manner suitable to the context of the rendering operation. For example, the view control for an may wish to display the error message in the tile's client area without crashing the control, whereas an image export routine may wish to notify the user via an error dialog and have the export output fail to be created. Automated routines (such as unit tests) may even wish that the exception bubble all the way to the top for debugging purposes.
member.param: A object that specifies the graphics surface and the scene graph to be rendered.
member.exception: Thrown if any is encountered in the rendering pipeline.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.IRenderingSurface
member.summary: Defines a rendering surface.

remarks.para: Unless you are implementing your own renderering surface, you should never have to interact with this interface. The two properties on should only ever have to be set by the Framework.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.IRenderingSurface.Type
member.summary: Gets the type of rendering surface.
member.remarks: Advanced implementations may need to provide different implementations of depending on whether the intended rendering destination is an onscreen window or an offscreen bitmap. For example, the onscreen surface may use a dynamic level-of-detail rendering in order to provide an update rate suitable for user interactivity. In contrast, the offscreen surface would always render at the highest level-of-detail in order to export the image to a memory bitmap.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.IRenderingSurface.WindowID
member.summary: Gets or sets the window ID.
member.remarks: On Windows systems, this is the window handle, or "hwnd" of the WinForms control you will eventually render to. This property is set by the Framework; you should never have to set this property yourself.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.IRenderingSurface.ContextID
member.summary: Gets or sets the context ID.
member.remarks: On Windows systems, this is the device context handle, or "hdc" of the WinForms control you will eventually render to. This property is set by the Framework; you should never have to set this property yourself.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.IRenderingSurface.ClientRectangle
member.summary: Gets or sets the rectangle of the surface.
member.remarks: This is the rectangle of the view onto the . The top-left corner is always (0,0). This rectangle changes as the view (i.e., the hosting window) changes size. Implementor should be aware that the rectangle can have a width or height of 0, and handle that boundary case appropriately.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.IRenderingSurface.ClipRectangle
member.summary: Gets or sets the rectangle that requires repainting.
member.remarks: The implementer of should use this rectangle to intelligently perform the operation. This property is set by the Framework; you should never have to set this property yourself.

member.name: E:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.IRenderingSurface.Invalidated

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.RenderingSurfaceType.Onscreen
member.summary: Indicates that the is suitable for onscreen use, and may have behaviours that only function correctly onscreen.
member.remarks: Advanced implementations may need to provide different implementations of depending on whether the intended rendering destination is an onscreen window or an offscreen bitmap. For example, the onscreen surface may use a dynamic level-of-detail rendering in order to provide an update rate suitable for user interactivity. In contrast, the offscreen surface would always render at the highest level-of-detail in order to export the image to a memory bitmap.

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.Rendering.RenderingSurfaceType.Offscreen
member.summary: Indicates that the is suitable for general purpose (offscreen) use.
member.remarks: Advanced implementations may need to provide different implementations of depending on whether the intended rendering destination is an onscreen window or an offscreen bitmap. For example, the onscreen surface may use a dynamic level-of-detail rendering in order to provide an update rate suitable for user interactivity. In contrast, the offscreen surface would always render at the highest level-of-detail in order to export the image to a memory bitmap.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.RoiGraphics.Roi
member.summary: Represents a static region of interest for the purposes of computing statistics on the contained pixels.

remarks.para: objects are static definitions of a region of interest on a particular image. Its shape definition and the underlying pixel values are considered fixed upon construction, and hence its various properties and statistics are non-changing.

New instances of a should be constructed everytime the definition of the region of interest or the underlying image pixel data has changed. The method allows client code to quickly construct a new instance of a based on the current definition of the graphic and the image it currently belongs to.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.RoiGraphics.Units
member.summary: Enumerated values defining the units of measurement used in various calculations in the namespace.
member.remarks: Depending on the specific context, the enumerated values can also represent areas or volumes. For example, if a method that computes area is given an argument of , then the output should be interpreted to be in square centimetres. Similarly, if a method that computes volume is given , then the output should be interpreted to be in cubic pixels.

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.RoiGraphics.Units.Pixels
member.summary: Indicates that the measurement is in units of image pixels (or square pixels, or cubic pixels).

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.RoiGraphics.Units.Millimeters
member.summary: Indicates that the measurement is in units of millimetres (or square millimetres, or cubic millimetres).

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.RoiGraphics.Units.Centimeters
member.summary: Indicates that the measurement is int units of centimetres (or square centimetres, or cubic centimetres).

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.WeightedWindowPrefetchingStrategy.DecompressionThreadConcurrency
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of concurrent threads to be used for frame pixel data decompression. Valid range is 0 or more.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.WeightedWindowPrefetchingStrategy.FrameLookAheadCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of frames to process in advance. Valid range is 0 or more.

remarks.para: The look-ahead is performed in both directions from the currently selected frame. The maximum possible window size would thus be 2 times the look-ahead size.
Setting the look-ahead size to null specifies an infinite look-ahead scope.

member.exception: Thrown if an attempt was made to set the property to an invalid value.
Thrown if an attempt was made to set the property when the strategy has already been started.

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.WeightedWindowPrefetchingStrategy.UnselectedImageBoxWeight

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.Frame
member.summary: Represents the DICOM concept of a frame.

remarks.para: The properties of this class, as well as its implementation of , represent a frame-normalized view of the attributes of the parent . When the SOP instance represents a multi-frame image, DICOM tags which have a singular invocation in the Multi-Frame Functional Groups Module will be mapped to the appropriate functional group instead of the root of the data set.

Additionally, some properties (such as ) will try to map to a different tag that represents the frame-level version of the same concept if possible (e.g. maps to in the functional groups first and, if that is unavailable, falls back to at the root level. This behaviour does not occur when accessing attributes directly via the indexers or the implementation - will only map to the functional group, and will only map to the root of the data set.

member.summary: Defines the methods and properties of the data source for a .

member.summary: Gets the 1-based numeric identifier of this frame.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.ISopFrameData.GetNormalizedPixelData
member.summary: Gets pixel data in normalized form (8 or 16-bit grayscale, or 32-bit ARGB).
member.remarks:
Normalized pixel data means that:
Grayscale pixel data has embedded overlays removed and each pixel value is padded so that it can be cast directly to the appropriate type (e.g. byte, sbyte, ushort, short).
Colour pixel data is always converted into ARGB format.
Pixel data is always uncompressed.
Ensuring that the pixel data always meets the above criteria allows clients to easily consume pixel data without having to worry about the the multitude of DICOM photometric interpretations and transfer syntaxes.
Pixel data is reloaded when this method is called after a call to .

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.ISopFrameData.GetNormalizedOverlayData(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the normalized overlay data buffer for a particular overlay group (8-bit grayscale).

remarks.para: Normalized overlay data means that the 1-bit overlay pixel data is extracted and unpacked as necessary to form an 8-bit-per-pixel buffer with values of either 0 or 255.

Ensuring that the overlay data always meets the above criteria allows clients to easily consume overlay data without having to worry about the storage of overlay data, whether embedded in unused bits of the pixel data or in a separate packed bits buffer.

Overlay data is reloaded when this method is called after a call to . The pixel data will also be reloaded if this method is called before and there are overlays stored in unused bits of the pixel data.

member.param: The 1-based overlay plane number.
member.returns: A byte buffer containing the normalized overlay pixel data.
member.exception: Thrown if is not a positive non-zero number.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.ISopFrameData.Unload
member.summary: Unloads any cached byte buffers owned by this .
member.remarks: It is sometimes necessary to manage the memory used by unloading the pixel data. Calling this method will not necessarily result in an immediate decrease in memory usage, since it merely releases the reference to the pixel data; it is up to the garbage collector to free the memory. Calling will reload the pixel data.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.ISopReference
member.summary: Interface defining a 'transient reference' to a .

remarks.para: In a Framework or SDK, managed objects often implement the pattern even when they don't explicitly contain any unmanaged resources. This is done in cases where it is possible, or perhaps very likely, that a derived class would in fact have unmanaged resources that need to be disposed or cleaned up. Such is the case with classes like .

Also, occasionally, the clear 'owner' of an object, particularly one that may be passed around from object to object, is not easy to determine, or simply doesn't exist. For managed objects that contain no unmanaged resources, this doesn't matter because the object(s) can simply be discarded and left for the garbage collector to clean up. But what about objects that must be disposed, but have no clear owner? One might argue that this points to a design flaw, and that may very well be correct in most cases. However, one totally valid case of this is objects that are cached for reasons of memory conservation, like , that must also implement . How do you determine when to properly dispose these objects when there is no one parent container that disposes them when it is itself disposed (for example, the or it's )? The only plausible way is to implement reference counting on the cached objects and only truly perform the disposal when the reference count goes to zero.

To solve all of these issues, enter the 'transient reference'. So, how does it work? Basically, each transient reference object can itself be 'owned' by another object and disposed at the time the owning object is disposed. This essentially allows many objects to reference the same shared/cached object, while also solving the problem of ownership. Each object owns its reference object, and the object it points to doesn't actually have to be explicitly owned at all! Instead, all the entities that own a transient reference essentially share ownership of the referenced object, and only once all the transient references are disposed is the underlying referenced object disposed. It's reference counting, but way better. Because the 'reference count' is always equal to the total number of transient reference objects, things are suddenly much easier to manage.

In the viewer framework, we don't typically work directly with s because the interface is far too basic to have to work with directly. Instead, we work with , and objects that are simply bridges (see Bridge Design Pattern) to and . The class is also the entity responsible for transparently managing the caching of the s passed to its constructor, therefore we work with 'transient references' to s and s instead of and .

The recommended practice, when taking a reference to a outside of it's current owner and holding a reference to it (like in the Clipboard, for example) is to get a transient reference to the or . When you are done with the transient reference, call Dispose on it. The object that owns the , normally the will dispose the , but internally, the will not do any cleanup until all transient references to it are also disposed. If you create a yourself, it is good practice to dispose the and all it's transient references in order to ensure the is released from the cache.

member.name: T:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.ISopDataSource
member.summary: Defines the methods and properties of the data source for a .

remarks.para:
A sop 'data source' is merely an abstraction of what is essentially just a . However, because the data is not always a simple local file, we have to account for the fact that there may be parts of the implementation that must be specialized because, for example, the data exists on a remote server and might be retrieved on demand or in stages. An example of this is the ClearCanvas Streaming implementation where:
A is initially constructed from an xml document retrieved from the server.
The xml document often will contain the entire image header, but unknown, private and large tags are excluded. When it is determined that a tag being requested is one of these tags, the will silently retrieve the entire image header on-demand.
Pixel data is always loaded on-demand in streaming and local cases.

Note that there is a significant shift in the design from previous versions of the framework, where did not exist and any specializations had to be done by deriving from . This caused a number of problems, the main one being that, when we added support for non-image s (like Key Objects) and became non-abstract, all of a sudden we had to create 2 specialized classes, one for and one for ; there was no way around it because client code depended on checking the type ( or ) in order to know whether or not it was an image. Also, and are rather large classes, and ultimately we realized that all they do is provide a convenient interface to a . So, why make developers inherit from , and and force them to have to figure out which of the many properties and methods to override when it's really not necessary? Also, now that we support non-image s, how come there's just and ? Where's KeyImageSop and PresentationStateSop? All of a sudden, we were headed down a very bad road. Such is development.

So how does make it easier? The biggest way has already been mentioned, which is that it unifies all sop instances, image or otherwise, under a single interface, so you only have to implement (and possibly ). has a few specialized bits of functionality for handling of large image data, such as pixel data and overlays, but that's it - everything else is the same as for non-images. The other nice thing about is that it can be used with the various convenient wrapper classes in , such as . The answer to the question "why isn't there a Key Object Sop?" is: there doesn't need to be. You can simply wrap the in whichever convenient IOD wrapper you need for a particular SOP class.

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.NormalizedPixelSpacingCalibrationType.CrossSectionalSpacing

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.NormalizedPixelSpacingCalibrationType.Detector

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.NormalizedPixelSpacingCalibrationType.Geometry
member.summary: Indicates that the pixel spacing has been calibrated for assumed or known geometric magnification effects at some unspecified depth within the patient for the projection image.

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.NormalizedPixelSpacingCalibrationType.Fiducial
member.summary: Indicates that the pixel spacing has been calibrated by measurement of an object (fiducial) of known size in the projection image.

member.name: F:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.NormalizedPixelSpacingCalibrationType.Magnified
member.summary: Indicates that the pixel spacing has been calibrated against the estimated radiographic magnification factor provided in the projection image.

member.summary: Provides access to an and the relevant .

remarks.para: If you have subclassed and want to expose an and to objects, do so by implementing this interface in your subclass.

In general, avoid accessing members of subclasses of directly. Prefer instead to use provider interfaces such as this one. Doing so prevents objects from having to know about specific subclasses of , thus allowing them to work with any type of that implements the provider interface.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.DicomMessageSopDataSource.NormalizeGrayscalePixels(ClearCanvas.Dicom.IDicomAttributeProvider,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Normalizes grayscale pixel data by masking out non-data bits and shifting the data bits to start at the lowest bit position.

remarks.para: The pixel data is normalized such that the effective high bit is precisely 1 less than bits stored. Filling of the high-order non-data bits is performed according to the sign of the pixel value when the pixel representation is signed, and always with 0 when the pixel reresentation is unsigned.

The provided is not updated with the effective high bit, nor is the attribute updated in any way. The only change is to the given pixel data buffer such that pixels can be read, 8 or 16 bits at a time, and interpreted immediately as or (or their signed equivalents and ).

member.param: A dataset containing information about the representation of pixels in the .
The pixel data buffer to normalize (for 16-bit samples, the data should be in machine order).

member.summary: Converts colour pixel data to ARGB.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.StandardSopDataSource.StandardSopFrameData.GetNormalizedPixelData
member.summary: Gets pixel data in normalized form (8 or 16-bit grayscale, or ARGB).
member.remarks:
Normalized pixel data means that:
Grayscale pixel data has embedded overlays removed and each pixel value is padded so that it can be cast directly to the appropriate type (e.g. byte, sbyte, ushort, short).
Colour pixel data is always converted into ARGB format.
Pixel data is always uncompressed.
Ensuring that the pixel data always meets the above criteria allows clients to easily consume pixel data without having to worry about the the multitude of DICOM photometric interpretations and transfer syntaxes.
Pixel data is reloaded when this method is called after a call to .

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.StandardSopDataSource.StandardSopFrameData.CreateNormalizedPixelData
member.summary: Called by to create a new byte buffer containing normalized pixel data for this frame (8 or 16-bit grayscale, or 32-bit ARGB).
member.remarks: See for details on the expected format of the byte buffer.
member.returns: A new byte buffer containing the normalized pixel data.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.StandardSopDataSource.StandardSopFrameData.GetNormalizedOverlayData(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the normalized overlay data buffer for a particular overlay group (8-bit grayscale).

remarks.para: Normalized overlay data means that the 1-bit overlay pixel data is extracted and unpacked as necessary to form an 8-bit-per-pixel buffer with values of either 0 or 255.

Ensuring that the overlay data always meets the above criteria allows clients to easily consume overlay data without having to worry about the storage of overlay data, whether embedded in unused bits of the pixel data or in a separate packed bits buffer.

Overlay data is reloaded when this method is called after a call to . The pixel data will also be reloaded if this method is called before and there are overlays stored in unused bits of the pixel data.

member.param: The 1-based overlay plane number.
member.returns: A byte buffer containing the normalized overlay pixel data.
member.exception: Thrown if is not a positive non-zero number.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.StandardSopDataSource.StandardSopFrameData.CreateNormalizedOverlayData(System.Int32)
member.summary: Called by to create a new byte buffer containing normalized overlay pixel data for a particular overlay plane.
member.remarks: See for details on the expected format of the byte buffer.
member.param: The 1-based overlay plane number.
member.returns: A new byte buffer containing the normalized overlay pixel data.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.StandardSopDataSource.StandardSopFrameData.Unload
member.summary: Unloads any cached byte buffers owned by this .
member.remarks: It is sometimes necessary to manage the memory used by unloading the pixel data. Calling this method will not necessarily result in an immediate decrease in memory usage, since it merely releases the reference to the pixel data; it is up to the garbage collector to free the memory. Calling will reload the pixel data.

member.summary: A DICOM Image SOP Instance.

remarks.para: Note that there should no longer be any need to derive from this class; the , and classes are now just simple Bridge classes (see Bridge Design Pattern) to and . See the remarks for for more information.
Also, for more information on 'transient references' and the lifetime of s, see .

member.name: P:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.ImageSop.Frames
member.summary: A collection of objects.
member.remarks: DICOM distinguishes between regular image SOPs and multiframe image SOPs. ClearCanvas, however, does not make this distinction, as it requires that two sets of client code be written. Instead, all image SOPs are considered to be multiframe, with regular images being a special case of a multiframe image with one frame. It can be assumed that all images contain at least one frame.

member.summary: Gets the number of frames in the image SOP.
member.remarks: Regular, non-multiframe DICOM images do not have this tag. However, because such images are treated as multiframes with a single frame, returns 1 in that case.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.ImageSop.GetFrameDimensionIndexValue(System.Int32,System.UInt32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Gets the Dimension Index Value of a specific dimension for the specified frame.
member.remarks: The Dimension Index Value is a number associated with a specific frame in a multi-frame image that identifies its sequential order relative to the other frames in a particular dimension. The dimension is identified by the DICOM tag which has the value of the frame in this dimension, and the DICOM tag of the parent functional group sequence.
member.param: The number of the frame for which the dimension is to be retrieved (1-based index).
The DICOM tag of the dimension to retrieve (i.e. the Dimension Index Pointer).
The DICOM tag of the parent functional group sequence (i.e. the Functional Group Pointer).
member.returns: The index value of the frame in the specified dimension, or NULL if the image is not a multi-frame or does not contain the specified dimension.

member.name: M:ClearCanvas.ImageViewer.StudyManagement.ImageSop.GetFrameDimensionOrganizationUid(System.Int32,System.UInt32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Gets the Dimension Organization UID of a specific dimension for the specified frame.
member.remarks: The Dimension Organization UID identifies when the same dimension index values are valid across multiple SOP instances.
member.param: The number of the frame for which the dimension is to be retrieved (1-based index).
The DICOM tag of the dimension to retrieve (i.e. the Dimension Index Pointer).
The DICOM tag of the parent functional group sequence (i.e. the Functional Group Pointer).
member.returns: The Dimension Organization UID of the specified dimension, or empty if the image is not a multi-frame or does not contain the specified dimension.
